awd_titl_txt: Developing Innovative Privacy Learning Modules to Engage Students in Cybersecurity Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid development of Internet services such as cloud computing, social networks, and mobile applications has increased attention to privacy protection by both industry and academia. Demand for information security is at an all-time high, creating an urgent shortfall in the national workforce. Despite recognized and critical societal needs, privacy education has not been integrated satisfactorily into undergraduate Computer Science (CS) curricula. A serious lack of effective learning materials to help students understand critical privacy concepts and gain hands-on skills has created a barrier to expanding privacy education. To address this concern and better prepare qualified graduates for the future U.S. workforce, researchers from Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) and the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga (UTC) will collaboratively develop hands-on learning materials on privacy protection and explore optimal integration of privacy into undergraduate cybersecurity education.

This project serves the national interest by designing and develop innovative learning modules on cutting-edge privacy topics identified by federal funding priorities to respond to the lack of hands-on based curriculum in privacy and cybersecurity education. These new self-contained learning modules with real-world hands-on labs will not only enrich the CS curricula at the two participating institutions (PVAMU and UTC), but also ensure that they can be easily adopted by other institutions. With these modules, the PIs will revamp related CS core and elective courses, and develop a new course on privacy, which will have profound impacts on both the CS curriculum and student learning at PVAMU and UTC. As an HBCU, underrepresented minorities at PVAMU will benefit from this project. In addition, the project will evaluate the effectiveness of an experiential learning approach based on student learning outcomes, experiences, and motivation, and attitudes toward privacy issues. Project research data, developed learning modules, and teaching materials will be actively disseminated to the research and educational community to benefit other institutions and enrich the NSF cybersecurity learning material repository.

por.por_cntn:
●      Award Title: Developing Innovative Privacy Learning Modules to Engage Students in Cybersecurity Education

●      Federal Award ID: 1712496

●      Report Submission Period: 08/01/2022 to 07/31/2023

 

To respond to the lack of hands-on based curriculum in privacy and cybersecurity education, this IUSE project initiated the design and development of innovative learning modules on the cutting-edge privacy topics, including Data Privacy (Anonymization and De-anonymization), Healthcare Privacy, Internet of Things (IoT) Privacy, Privacy on Social Media, Location Privacy, Web Tracking, Network Privacy, and Image Privacy. Particularly, several labware have been successfully designed and implemented to teach corresponding privacy concepts, which enables students to gain first-hand experience and understand how to solve real-world privacy problems.

Several scholar articles have been published about the development of the labware and the students’ feedback. One new course, called Information Privacy, has been developed and taught at Prairie View A&M University in the spring of 2020. Additionally, several labs have been conducted in security classes at PVAMU and UTC and a student seminar at PVAMU in the fall of 2019. The results from the pre and post surveys indicate that students were very engaged in learning privacy concepts through the hands-on activities with the developed labware. These developed modules are self-contained, encapsulating the hands-on labs and related lecture contents. Therefore, they can be infused into teaching different security and privacy subjects and be easily adapted by other institutions. From the two faculty summer workshops organized in 2019 and 2022 respectively, participating faculty indicated great interest in adapting the developed materials into their classes.

 

Additionally, the project provided the investigators with invaluable opportunities to conduct research on privacy and educational research and fostered expertise pollination among the faculty at PVAMU and UTC and long term collaboration between the two institutions. This project also has sponsored several undergraduate and graduate students who were engaged in doing research and developing labware on different privacy related topics. These students were well trained on programming and research skills. Finally, the investigators have disseminated the project outcomes to the scientific community through scholarly publications at prestigious international conferences, summer workshops, and student seminars. A Cybersecurity Concentration has been established in the Department of Computer Science at PVAMU since the fall of 2020. More students have been attracted to the field of Cybersecurity.

 

In summary, this project, as a collaboration between a Historically Black College and University (PVAMU) and an institution with the National Security Agency designated National Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance/Cyber Defense (UTC), has been very successful and enriched the NSF cybersecurity learning material repository and motivated students’ interests in cybersecurity, and strengthened their understanding of privacy issues.

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2023
Modified by: Na Li
